messageBody:
Jason Rogers wrote:

> On Tue, 13 Jan 2004 13:06:20 -0500, J. B. Rainsberger <jbrains@...>
> wrote:
>
>>karthikeyand wrote:

>>>Hi,
>>> while writing tests for testing EJB code , for eg., we need to
>>>insert some rows (thru entity ejb) and test the creation ,
>>>relationships etc., but before exiting the testcase i need to remove
>>>the new rows (or entity objects) entered before executing the test
>>>case .So the creation of the rows and removing the rows are done only
>>>once in the test case which might contain many testXXX() methods. So
>>>is there a standard approach for the above said scenario.
>>
>>This is exactly what tearDown() is for: to "tear down" your test
>>fixture. In general, whatever you do in setUp(), you do the opposite in
>>tearDown().
>
> Sounds like <karthikeyand> is talking about the need for a one-time
> setup. If that be so, please search the archives or JUnit documentation
> for TestSetup. It takes care of one-time operations.

Ah, yes. As always, Jason is on the mark.
